results.title: David
results.creator_credit: Tom Kelly and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
David is a young actor with Down’s Syndrome, chosen to portray a mentally handicapped adolescent in a Canadian television play. Points out society’s unwillingness to accept potential from those with Down’s. David speaks about his condition to a school class and is shown skating, swimming, jogging and cycling, and interacting with family and friends. Suitable for middle and upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: David
results.creator_credit: James Carr, World Wide Pictures, BFI and Paul Dickson
results.brief_description: Illustrates the harsh reality of life in a coal mining town using documentary and fictional techniques. Made in Ammanford, Wales, the film recounts the life of Daffyd Rhys employed as a caretaker for the local school following a coal mine explosion. The story is related by one of the school’s former pupils and covers Daffyd’s early life in the coal mines, his courtship and marriage, his work as a poet, the death of his son, and his life at the school. Most of the roles are performed by the people of Ammanford resulting in a realistic portrayal of life in the Welsh coal mining community. The film was presented as Wales contribution to the Festival of Britain.

results.title: Dave's story
results.brief_description: In this short monologue the narrator reveals a crucial moment in his young life - when his high school teacher revealed the secret to happiness. Made as part of the ‘Pride and Diversity’ workshop in association with Vic Health.

results.title: Daumier
results.creator_credit: Mary Van Den Heyer and Nico Crama
results.brief_description: Daumier was a ninteenth century eyewitness of England and Europe: the observer of great and small men. This film shows some of his lighographic cartoons and caricatures which relate to the period 1830-1873.

results.title: Dating
results.creator_credit: Pat Hunder, Garry Dunstan and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
Examines dating and focuses on the “first date” for teenagers. Looks at dating from the point of view of girls and boys, and first date etiquette. Also examines how other cultures see their children in relation to dating.

results.title: Date with history: Hiroshima
results.brief_description: Shows the preliminary events leading up to the bombing of Hiroshima in August, 1945 in which 72,000 people were killed. some of the people involved are interviewed, giving their reactions to the holocaust. The film contains actual footage of the events.
results.description: Shows the preliminary events leading up to the bombing of Hiroshima in August, 1945 in which 72,000 people were killed. some of the people involved are interviewed, giving their reactions to the holocaust. The film contains actual footage of the events.

results.title: Date with Dizzy
results.creator_credit: Jim Di Gangi, Hubley Films and John Hubley
results.brief_description: A gentle satire on television commercials showing the production and use of effective advertising. Features Dizzy Gillespie and Quintet improvising a musical soundtrack for drawings made by John Hubley and his staff as they create animated-cartoon television commercials for a new product with unsuccessful results until the director screens three previous advertisements as examples of the desired effect. Concludes with a wild jam session led by Dizzy Gillespie. Several of the Hubley animation techniques are illustrated making this film useful for discussion on film technique.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jim Di Gangi, Hubley Films and John Hubley

results.title: Date of birth
results.creator_credit: Michael Spencer, ONF | NFB and Donald Fraser
results.brief_description: A tribute to the older worker’s high standard of dependability and productivity, and a plea to employers to remove age barriers in hiring new staff. The bitter disappointment felt by an able man denied work because he is over forty-five is expressed in a brief dramatic sequence, and then the film presents the actual record of employees in this age group, reminding us that there is less absenteeism, a lower turnover rate and an equal standard of production among older workers. The importance to the whole country of giving a fair chance to workers over forty-five years of age is explained, and ways in which their problem is being tackled are described.
